head.title: House Backs Bill To Ban Net Fees

hedline.hl1: House Backs Bill To Ban Net Fees

abstract.p: US House unanimously endorses bill that would prohibit federal fees on Internet access (S)

block.p: The House tried to put to rest today longstanding Internet rumors of pending e-mail taxes, unanimously endorsing a bill that would prohibit federal fees on Internet access.
Although sponsors of the bill lauded it as crucial for protecting consumers from potential new costs, opponents said it was unnecessary. The Federal Communications Commission called it superfluous.
The House tried to put to rest today longstanding Internet rumors of pending e-mail taxes, unanimously endorsing a bill that would prohibit federal fees on Internet access.
Although sponsors of the bill lauded it as crucial for protecting consumers from potential new costs, opponents said it was unnecessary. The Federal Communications Commission called it superfluous.
''What we are considering today is a fabricated solution to an imaginary problem,'' said Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan.

The bill, by two Republican Representatives, Fred Upton of Michigan and Robert W. Goodlatte of Virginia, would prohibit the F.C.C. from imposing a per-minute access fee on Internet use, like that imposed on long-distance telephone calls.
The commission has never proposed such a fee. But it has been the subject of Internet rumors for nearly two years.

''Not long ago, a rumor began to circulate about bill H.B. 602P, sponsored by a fictitious Congressman Schnell, which would impose an access fee on per-minute Internet use,'' Mr. Goodlatte said in a statement. ''Although there is no such bill and no such Congressman, constituents wrote and called by the thousands expressing their outrage.''
